items.title: U.S. Senate Republicans veto legislation to limit Trump's ability to attack Venezuela
items.summary_auto: Senate Republicans voted to reject legislation Thursday that would have put a check on U.S. President Donald Trump's ability to launch an attack against Venezuela, as Democrats pressed Congress to take a stronger role in Trump's high-stakes campaign against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

items.title: How the son of Russian spies paved the legal path for B.C. ostrich cull
items.summary_auto: In his battle for Canadian citizenship, Alexander Vavilov got an opportunity denied to the owners of B.C. 's Universal Ostrich Farms — a chance to argue his case before Canada's top court. In the process, the son of Russian spies set a legal standard for decision-making "reasonableness" that would doom the B.C. birds six years later.

items.title: In the shadow of U.S. withdrawal, leaders urge action at COP30 UN climate summit in Brazil
items.summary_auto: Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva hopes to convince world powers to mobilize enough funds to halt the ongoing destruction of climate-stabilizing tropical rainforests in danger around the world and advance the many unmet promises laid out at previous meetings.

items.title: U.S. deal could cut costs for popular weight-loss drugs. What’s that mean for Canada?
items.summary_auto: A new deal with major drugmakers, unveiled by U.S. President Donald Trump on Thursday, aims to expand coverage and cut prices for popular weight-loss drugs south of the border. So how much could Trump’s announcement really cut costs? And will Canadians also benefit?

items.title: Musk could become world's 1st trillionaire as Tesla shareholders approve giant pay package
items.summary_auto: Elon Musk won a shareholder vote on Thursday that would give the Tesla CEO stock worth $1 trillion if he hits certain performance targets over the next decade, handing him a chance to become history's first trillionaire.

items.title: Teachers' union taking Alberta government to court over notwithstanding clause
items.summary_auto: The Alberta Teachers’ Association has filed a constitutional challenge of a provincial government law that forced educators across the province back to work and imposed a new contract.

items.title: Alberta RCMP officers won't be charged in fatal shooting of 15-year-old boy: police watchdog
items.summary_auto: An Alberta Serious Response Incident Team investigation says the officers shot at the teenager up to 17 times as he came toward them in a field, holding his arm up in a backpack so that it appeared he was pointing a gun.

items.title: 'We miss you': Kalispell, Mont., launches campaign to woo back Canadian visitors
items.summary_auto: One of Montana's main travel destinations is reaching out to Canadians, offering deals, discounts and specials in an effort to lure them back for a visit. Discover Kalispell, a tourism marketing and management organization for the city in northwest Montana, has unveiled its Kalispell Canadian Welcome Pass.

items.title: Man who threw sandwich at U.S. federal agent found not guilty of assault
items.summary_auto: The man who threw a sandwich and became symbol of resistance to U.S. President Donald Trump's D.C. law enforcement surge has been found not guilty of assault.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Scenes from Prince Harry's visit in Toronto
items.summary_auto: Prince Harry, who served in Afghanistan as a member of the British military, is attending several events in Toronto commemorating veterans ahead of Remembrance Day.

items.title: Danielle Smith wants climate laws scrapped before Grey Cup. What will she offer in return?
items.summary_auto: Before the 112th Grey Cup gets underway next week, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith is expecting a major chapter to unfold in the long-running federal-provincial battle over energy policy. But there are still unanswered questions.

items.title: The northern lights could light up the sky on Thursday night
items.summary_auto: Keep your fingers crossed for clear skies: the U.S. Space Weather Prediction Center is calling for a strong geomagnetic storm, which could produce the northern lights.

items.title: New N.S. study finds microplastics in edible portions of lobster tails
items.summary_auto: Dalhousie University researchers found an average of six to seven microplastic particles per gram of meat.

items.title: AI artist Xania Monet has hit the Billboard charts. What does it mean for 'real' musicians?
items.summary_auto: Xania Monet has become the first AI-generated artist to debut on a Billboard airplay chart — and her success is raising questions about what the future could hold for human artists looking to achieve the same feat.

items.title: Ontario Grade 8 teacher pleads guilty to sex crimes against students
items.summary_auto: An Ontario Grade 8 teacher who used Snapchat to send and solicit nude pictures from former students has pleaded guilty to luring and child pornography charges.

items.title: What's in store for Ontario's economy? Slower growth and a challenging labour market: province
items.summary_auto: Ontario's deficit projection is shrinking in its fall fiscal update, but so are the province's expectations for the labour market as U.S. tariffs are expected to continue hitting the economy.

items.title: Boeing officially off the hook for criminal charges in deadly crashes that killed 346 people
items.summary_auto: A U.S. judge on Thursday approved a request by the Justice Department to dismiss a criminal case against Boeing stemming from two fatal 737 MAX plane crashes that killed 346 people including 18 Canadians.

items.title: MEG-Cenovus deal clears key shareholder vote after delays
items.summary_auto: MEG Energy Corp. shareholders have given their blessing to an $8.6-billion takeover by fellow oilsands producer Cenovus Energy Inc.

items.title: Prince Harry jokes he was 'under duress' while wearing Dodgers cap at World Series
items.summary_auto: Prince Harry joked in Toronto that he was "under duress" when he wore a Los Angeles Dodgers hat during a World Series game against the Blue Jays last week.

items.title: Body of 2nd victim in fatal Brampton, Ont., crash only discovered once car was in police impound lot
items.summary_auto: Peel police say that the second victim in a crash involving a youth driver in Brampton Saturday was found hours after the collision, after the two vehicles had already been transported to the police impound yard.

items.title: Supreme Court will hear appeals of Saskatchewan's school pronoun law
items.summary_auto: No date has been set for the court to hear the cross appeals from the provincial government and UR Pride on the province's school pronoun law, which prevents children under 16 from changing their names or pronouns at school without parental consent.

items.title: Sudan's paramilitary force agrees to U.S. proposal for humanitarian ceasefire
items.summary_auto: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) agreed to a proposal from the United States for a humanitarian ceasefire, the group said on Thursday in a statement.

items.title: Man pleads guilty to 'monstrous' 2024 stabbing attack that killed 6
items.summary_auto: The man behind a mass stabbing in Ottawa last year — described by the judge as a "monstrous, even demonic" act — pleaded guilty Thursday.

items.title: Cartel-fighting mayor’s assassination in Mexico’s avocado heartland fuels citizen fury
items.summary_auto: Uruapan Mayor Carlos Manzo’s killing triggered a spasm of fury that has fuelled protests across the fertile Mexican state of Michoacan, which produces limes and avocados found on Canadian grocery shelves.

items.title: Israel strikes south Lebanon despite ceasefire, says it’s targeting Hezbollah military sites
items.summary_auto: Israeli jets struck several towns in southern Lebanon on Thursday, marking an escalation in their near-daily strikes on the country.

items.title: David Common announced as CBC’s new Morning Live host
items.summary_auto: Veteran reporter and current Metro Morning radio host David Common will replace Heather Hiscox as host of CBC Morning Live, the Crown corporation announced Thursday. The announcement comes on the same day as Hiscox’s final broadcast as host and 20 years after she first took over the position.

items.title: Hundreds of ostriches at B.C. farm to be killed after top court dismisses appeal to stop cull
French auditor's report raps Louvre for excessive art acquisitions even as most rooms lacked cameras
items.summary_auto: France's Louvre Museum began a security audit a decade ago but the recommended upgrades will not be completed until 2032, the state auditor said in a report on Thursday compiled before a spectacular heist there last month.

items.title: Vietnam evacuates hundreds of thousands as Typhoon Kalmaegi lands after leaving 114 dead in Philippines
items.summary_auto:
Typhoon Kalmaegi slammed into Vietnam on Thursday, forcing authorities to cancel hundreds of flights and order people to 
stay indoors, two days after the storm started sweeping across the Philippines, killing at least 114 people.

items.title: Hereditary cancer, high cholesterol risk for 100,000 Canadians to be checked in genetic screening project
items.summary_auto: Over the the next five years, up to 100,000 people in Ontario will be screened for genetic conditions that increase their risk of hereditary cancers and a condition tied to high cholesterol and heart disease, says Princess Margaret Cancer Centre.

items.title: Here's how much money you needed to make to be among Nova Scotia's top earners
items.summary_auto: New numbers from Statistics Canada reveal how much the highest-income Nova Scotians make. The information is based on tax filings for 2023.

items.title: Margaret Atwood on reading palms, getting older — and holding grudges
items.summary_auto: Margaret Atwood’s new memoir Book of Lives explores how the world has shaped her writing, and how that writing in turn shaped her life

items.title: The budget aims for a permanent school food program. But that doesn't mean free lunches for everyone
items.summary_auto: School food advocates welcome the federal budget pledge for a permanent national program with dedicated funding annually. Yet given the current patchwork of offerings in place, experts say there's much work ahead to ensure all kids can access a robust and sustainable food program at school.

items.title: Did Bill Gates really say we don't need to address climate change?
items.summary_auto: Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist Bill Gates has been in the news of late, with claims that he has changed his stance on climate change, following a memo he posted on his website. But is that really the case?

items.title: The hidden humans powering the AI economy
items.summary_auto: We usually hear two sides to the AI and employment story: star engineers earning enormous salaries, and job loss for many others. But from gig workers paid poorly to annotate data, to people with advanced degrees training specialized AI, it takes a huge labour force to develop AI.
